verb.description: Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition)
examples: the powers accorded to the head of state
the national assembly accorded the General more power

verb.description: (of a concept or fact) be harmonious or consistent with.

phrases: That relationship was conditional, only for certain things, in accord with the laws of each country, and with the customs of those so engaged.
Maclean retained his early idealism and lived a life fully in accord with his Communist principles, eschewing all privileges.
Liberals now lambast him daily for failing to act through multilateral institutions and in accord with international law.
Even very stupid bots can appear intelligent if they are acting in accord with our preconceptions.
She is indulging her passion for running other people's lives in accord with her own personal prejudices.
origin: Old English, from Old French acorder reconcile, be of one mind, from Latin ad- to + cor, cord- heart; influenced by concord.
